title: From fishing port to tourist hotspot: how skyscrapers came to dominate Benidorm – in pictures
description: Photographer Didier Bizet takes a look at Benidorm, one of the most visited tourist destinations in Europe and a favourite of Britons. Construction in ‘Beni York’ has led to the rise of 370 towers above 12 storeys tall, making it the second most densely packed urban area with skyscrapers – after New York Continue reading...
author: Photographs by Didier Bizet
excerpt: Photographer Didier Bizet takes a look at Benidorm, one of the most visited tourist destinations in Europe. Construction in ‘Beni York’ has made it the second most densely packed urban area with skyscrapers – after New York
text: While the main Benidorm beach, stretching over 3km in length and furnished with thousands of sun loungers, overflows with sunburned bodies, Benidorm’s streets resemble an amusement park set, where giant point-of-sale displays fuel a consumerist frenzy The Co Blanca V residence, with its circular balconies, was built in 1972 by architect Juan Guardiola Gaia Photograph: Didier Bizet The Benidorm Palace car circulates every day in the late afternoon to promote nightlife, such as cabarets and shows Levante Beach stretches over 3km and is equipped with 4,600 sunbeds Photograph: Didier Bizet In the early evening, people gather at the Plaça del Castell, the old castle of Benidorm that once defended the city from pirates. Musicians, artists, vendors, and portrait artists gather in this small square of old Benidorm Two tourists on their rental scooter gaze at the Bay of Benidorm. Sixty years have passed since the fishing village with its olive tree hills became a resort town The seaside resort has transformed into a city with an American look, focused on consumption Playmon Park, originally built as a residential complex in the early 1970s, has gradually lost value and prestige since its heyday A view of a street in the modern district. The Mediterranean’s ‘Manhattan’, with its brutalist, modernist, and functionalist architecture, sees an influx of about 3 million visitors yearly View of the north facade of the Cumbre Loix residence, which was built in the early 1970s. It houses swimming pools, tennis courts, and a shopping centre Two young women sit at a table in a fast-food restaurant A facade of a residence in the centre of Benidorm Tourists taking pictures at the Plaça del Castell Although he was not a trained architect, Pedro Zaragoza, mayor of Benidorm from 1950 to 1974, was undoubtedly one of the most influential figures in the city’s development. He promoted a modern urban vision and supported the construction of skyscrapers to maximise land use. A shopping street near the beachfront In Finestrat Street, the British pub district fills up by 5pm, and the police often intervene during some overly drunk nights Photograph: Didier Bizet The Benidorm police have launched a crackdown on tourists renting mobility scooters and have fined them up to €500 (£425) after it was revealed that many of them were falsely claiming to be disabled in order to rent them. The situation is becoming increasingly difficult to control and is causing numerous accidents Photograph: Didier Bizet Young people in one of the McDonald’s in the city as they protect themselves from the afternoon heat Photograph: Didier Bizet Benidorm Island is the only island in front of the city that is open for visits. The island is a rock with a single bar Photograph: Didier Bizet Boats make round-trips every hour from the port. The only attraction is the view of Benidorm Bay Photograph: Didier Bizet What is the future of these cities transformed by mass tourism? Faced with ever-increasing visitor numbers, the former small fishing port of Benidorm is trying to promote community-oriented tourism
